This is a good solution, but not the most accurate one. Rather than using constant numbers (7, 8, and 9): (1) we generate a uniformly distributed value from range 0 to 1, and (2) we generate a CDF of a specific distribution, and sample from this CDF (e.g. zipf, uniform etc..).. Note that step number (2) is the values that the answer in stackoverflow compares against (7, 8 and 9).

I wrote this code once in python, I am constructing the whole CDF, because the elements number was large:
def random_pick(alist, probs):
    x = random.uniform(0, 1)
    cumulative_probability = 0.0
    selected_item = None
    for item, item_probability in zip(alist, probs):
        cumulative_probability += item_probability
        if x < cumulative_probability:
            selected_item = item
            break
    return selected_item

Note that "probs" is the PDF of a specific distribution (not the CDF). For more information  Allen Downey has a nice and simple free ebook "Think Stats"
